importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the LEAP trial findings were published and new medical guidelines were issued recommending early introduction of peanuts to infants, leading to a significant shift in pediatric allergy prevention practices.
The year when expanded recommendations for early allergen introduction were issued, leading to a further decline in peanut allergy rates among children.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The decade-long period during which early peanut introduction has been implemented and its real-world impact on reducing peanut allergy incidence has been observed and measured.

keyTakeAways: The rate of peanut allergies in children aged 0 to 3 fell by more than 27% after 2015 and by over 40% after 2017 due to medical guidance recommending early introduction of peanuts.
About 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015, according to the study, not 60,000 as previously reported.
Early allergen introduction, particularly of peanuts, has been shown to reduce the future risk of food allergies by over 80% in children, with protection persisting in about 70% into adolescence.
New research analyzing electronic health records confirms that early peanut introduction is being adopted and is making a measurable public health impact.
The current 2021 updated guidelines recommend introducing peanuts and other major allergens between four and six months of age, without prior screening or testing.

Health professionals and parents are encouraged to consult with pediatricians about introducing small amounts of peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters as safe ways to expose infants to allergens.
Despite the evidence, adoption among medical professionals has been slow—only about 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists reported following the expanded 2017 guidance.
The 2015 LEAP trial by Gideon Lack at King’s College London was a landmark study that changed clinical practice and public health recommendations on food allergy prevention.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after the landmark LEAP trial showed that early introduction of peanuts to infants reduces the risk of developing food allergies, new research confirms that real-world implementation has led to a significant decline in peanut allergy rates—by over 27% after 2015 and over 40% after 2017. The study, led by Dr. David Hill at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia and published in Pediatrics, analyzed electronic health records and found that about 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015. This public health shift, rooted in the 2015 LEAP trial by Gideon Lack at King’s College London, which demonstrated over 80% reduction in allergy risk, is now being adopted by parents and medical professionals, despite initial hesitancy. The updated 2021 guidelines recommend introducing allergens like peanuts, peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, and soy-based yogurt between 4 and 6 months of age without prior screening. Experts emphasize that early exposure through small, safe tastes can help prevent allergies, and organizations like FARE support this approach as a critical public health strategy.
title: Early Peanut Introduction in Infants Reduces Allergy Rates, Study Finds
